    Cubanes in Medicinal Chemistry

    • Tristan A. Reekie
      Tristan A. Reekie
      School of Chemistry, The University of Sydney, Sydney, NSW 2006, Australia
      More by Tristan A. Reekie
      View Biography

      Craig M. Williams
      School of Chemistry and Molecular Biosciences, University of Queensland, Brisbane, QLD 4072, Australia

      Louis M. Rendina

      More by Louis M. Rendina
      View Biography

    Abstract

    Cubane is a highly strained saturated hydrocarbon system that has historically been of interest in theoretical organic chemistry. More recently it has become a molecule of interest for biological applications due to its inherent stability and limited toxicity. Of greater significance is the ability to potentially functionalize cubane at each of its carbon atoms, providing complex biologically active molecules with unique spatial arrangements for probing active sites. These characteristics have led to an increased use of cubane in pharmaceutically relevant molecules. In this Perspective we describe synthetic methodology for accessing a range of functionalized cubanes and their applications in pharmaceuticals. We also provide some perspectives on challenges and future directions in the advancement of this field.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    On first glance, pentacyclo[4.2.0.02,5.03,8.04,7]octane, or simply cubane (1), looks to be an unrealistic framework for organic chemistry. However, this view could not be further from the truth, as cubane and its substituted derivatives have found multiple applications in varied chemical fields. Cubane is thermodynamically unstable and highly strained, with the geometry around the carbon atom being far removed from tetrahedral. Importantly though, no kinetically viable path exists for its thermal rearrangement, meaning that cubane is stable up to 220 Â°C, and even then decomposition is slow.(1) It is the high energy, but relative stability of cubane, combined with its high density that saw its initial application in explosives. It has only been in recent years that cubane has made its impact in the field of medicinal chemistry, making it a chemical moiety with significant potential as a robust scaffold.(2) There have been previous reviews of cubane that cover its history and application outside the field of medicinal chemistry,(2â4) whereas this Perspective will discuss its relatively recent impact in drug design, including potential opportunities in unexplored areas, and future challenges.

    Characteristics of Cubane

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The interest in cubane for pharmaceutical incorporation arises from the idea that it can act as a bioisostere of benzene (2), first proposed by Eaton.(2) The distance between the body diagonal of cubane (2.72 Ã) matches closely with that of benzene (2.79 Ã) (Figure 1),(5) even though the individual CâC bond lengths are slightly longer (1.573 Ã vs 1.397 Ã).(6) Cubane has the benefit over its benzene isostere in that it is biologically stable and there is no inherent toxicity associated with this molecule as compared to benzene.(2) Further benefits exist with cubane in that the eight contact points allow for substitution in defined 3D-spatial arrangements, including what can be considered âaboveâ (A) and âbelowâ (B) the benzene plane, in addition to âwithinâ (C) the benzene plane (Figure 1).(2) However, and as will be discussed later, there are multiple practical synthetic considerations that currently hamper the full exploration of these key spatial arrangements.
    Additional benefits attributed to cubane include its complete stability to light, air, and moisture and its relatively high melting point of 130â131 Â°C.(7) These attributes were capitalized upon, in addition to both the hydrogen and carbon atoms resonating at uniquely reliable chemical shifts, for the promotion of cubane itself as the ideal internal NMR standard.(8) As will be outlined below, cubane is also stable to most common reagents, allowing for synthetic manipulation without disrupting its key core structure.
    Due to the highly strained geometry of the cubane system, the CâC bonds take on much more p-character, which in turn provide the CâH bonds with increased s-character. As a result, the CâH bond is much more acidic than what is observed for unstrained hydrocarbons.(9) Neighboring-group participation allows for ortho lithiation with LiTMP,(10) though transmetalation is generally required to give a more useful transformation.(10â12) Despite the unfavorable considerations behind the generation of a cubyl cation, such as geometry and high s-character of the exocyclic orbitals, experimental evidence has been provided that supports facile formation of a cubyl cation.(13) Its formation is attributed to the p-character of the CâC bonds allowing for charge delocalization by donation of electron density to the cationic center.(14) Furthermore, no cationic rearrangement of the cubane skeleton is observed. Finally, the existence of cubyl radicals has been shown through a combination of practical and computational experiments.(15â21)

    Synthesis of Cubane and Monosubstituted Building Blocks

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cubane was first synthesized and reported by Eaton and Cole in 1964,(7) closely following on their earlier work wherein they synthesized dimethyl 1,4-cubanedicarboxylate (3).(22) Chapman and co-workers reported several modifications to this protocol utilizing cyclopentadienone ethylene ketal (4) as the starting material.(23) Tsanaktsidis and co-workers integrated key elements of the Eaton and Chapman approaches to describe an improved protocol for the production of kilogram quantities of 3, which has become the key building block for cubane-based chemistry (Scheme 1).(24,25) Tribromination of 4 using 3 equiv of bromine affords the intermediate 5 that, following bromide elimination, undergoes DielsâAlder dimerization to afford 6. Ketal removal affords 7 that engages in a [2Ï + 2Ï] eneâenone photocyclization, with subsequent hydrolysis of dimethyl ketals that form during the reaction, to afford caged compound 8. A double Favorskii ring contraction, followed by acidification and then methyl ester formation, converts 8 into the solid dimethyl 1,4-cubanedicarboxylate (3) in 22% overall yield on kilogram scales.
    Given the ready accessibility of 3, various methods have been used to convert this starting material into synthetic building blocks (Scheme 2). Monoester hydrolysis of 3 affords 9 that can then undergo a Barton decarboxylation to afford the monosubstituted ester 10.(26,27) Hydrolysis affords the acid 11, which could be reduced to the alcohol 12, though direct reduction from the methyl ester 10 gives higher yields.(18,28) Alternatively, the carboxylic acid can be converted to the primary amine hydrochloride 13 or the aminomethyl derivative 14a.(29) The alcohol 12 can be further converted to the bromo derivative 15(30) or the sulfonyl chloride 16 via the corresponding thioacetate.(28) The monomethyl ester 10 can be homologated to the cubanyl acetic acid 17(28,30) or converted to the Weinreb amide 18, allowing for further functionalization, as exemplified by the formation of alkyne 19.(28)
    Compounds 9â19 provide multiple varied handles for incorporating cubane into larger molecules, though other building blocks have been generated, as shown in Figure 2. Substituted cubanes with a simple functionality, such as an aldehyde,(31) thiol,(32) alcohol,(33) nitrile,(34) and alkyne and azide(35) moieties, have all been generated (compounds 20â25, respectively). The aldehyde is best utilized in situ as it can readily decompose when isolated in pure form, and Eaton postulated that hydroxyl-substituted cubanes can readily undergo rearrangement via a ketene intermediate.(2,32) Hydroxy acid 26, accessible from ester 10, can also be used to generate amino acid substituted cubane 27, while analogs 28 and 29 are accessible from 20 and 12, respectively.(36) In the case of 27, the Boc and methyl ester protected compound can undergo chiral (enantioselective) HPLC separation that affords, following deprotection, (+)- and (â)-27.(36) The cyanoformamide 30 has been prepared as an electrophilic carbonyl source to incorporate the cubyl amide directly.(37) The nitrile 31 has also been prepared and used to generate isoxazole cubane 32 with a primary amine for further functionalization.(28) Alternatively, the imidazole heterocycle 33 can be generated, also with a nucleophilic nitrogen atom.(28)

    Monosubstituted Cubanes in Pharmaceuticals

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    With the accessibility of key monosubstituted cubane building blocks, the cubane motif has begun to appear in pharmaceutically relevant molecules. One of the first examples of using a cubane compound for biological applications was (aminomethyl)cubane (14), which was found to inhibit monoamine oxidase-B (Figure 3).(38) Rather than looking to develop a pharmaceutical, 14 was used as a tool compound to probe the mechanism by which the enzyme is able to oxidize amine containing neurotransmitters.
    The strategic replacement of key moieties with cubane in pharmaceutical leads was demonstrated with the development of morphine analogs 34c and 35c (Figure 3).(39) Morphine (34a, Ki = 38 nM and 1870 nM at Î¼ and Îº opioid receptors, respectively) and oxymorphone (35a, Ki = 15 nM and 725 nM at Î¼ and Îº opioid receptors, respectively) are potent opioid ligands while N-allyl derivatives (34b and 35b, respectively) are at least 8-fold more potent. The similar electronic and steric character of the cubylmethyl and the N-allyl and N-cyclopropylmethyl moieties makes for an interesting comparison. At both the Î¼ and Îº opioid receptors, binding was improved when comparing the N-methylated compounds 34a and 35a with the cubane substituted compounds 34c (Ki = 17.3 nM and 107 nM at Î¼ and Îº opioid receptors, respectively) and 35c (Ki = 13.6 nM and 19.5 nM at Î¼ and Îº opioid receptors, respectively). However, the most potent binding was still observed with derivatives 34b (Ki = 4.5 nM and 131 nM at Î¼ and Îº opioid receptors, respectively) and 34b (Ki = 1.1 nM and 12 nM at Î¼ and Îº opioid receptors, respectively). This improvement was rationalized because while the cubane maintained the favorable electronics of 34b and 35b, the larger size of cubylmethyl compared to allyl and cyclopropylmethyl groups introduced unfavorable steric interactions.
    Structureâactivity relationships (SARs) that incorporate the cubane moiety have normally involved it as an isostere for a phenyl group or as a substitute for cyclic or polycyclic functionality. Validation of Eatonâs hypothesis stating cubane is a benzene isostere has only recently been reported.(40) In doing so, the authors investigated known pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals that contain phenyl rings and generated their cubane analogs. Two of the monosubstituted cubane derivatives are shown in Figure 4. Compound 36a (suberoylanilide hydroxamic acid, SAHA) is a histone deacetylase inhibitor approved for treatment of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.(41,42) The cubane analog 36b, in a side-by-side assessment with 36a, obtained comparative IC50 values against tumor cells and was significantly less toxic against neonatal foreskin fibroblasts (NFF) primary cells.(40) Further comparisons were conducted in vivo, with both compounds demonstrating significant reduction in tumor growth compared to vehicle. Furthermore, both compounds performed almost identically in these studies. Experimentally determined logÂ PHPLC values for 36a and 36b were also reported as 0.99 and 1.52, showing an increase of lipophilicity by substituting a phenyl for cubyl moiety.
    Benzyl benzoate (37a) can be used to kill mites that are responsible for causing the scabies skin disease.(43) Three cubane analogs 37bâd were synthesized substituting either one or both phenyl groups. While 37a exerts complete acaricide after 5 min, the most potent cubane derivative 37d took 24 h to elicit 55% mortality. These results show that a phenyl to cubane swap of a drug lead will not always retain or enhance biological function, but in this instance, it could be attributed to the increased lipophilicity obtained when substituting in cubyl moieties. Compound 37a had a logÂ PHPLC value of 3.86, but for 37bâd, values of 5.43, 5.10, and 4.22 respectively, were determined. Given this, compound solubility became challenging, requiring mineral oil to act as the delivery vehicle. The most active cubyl analogue, 37d, was also that with the lowest lipophilicity, suggesting that solubility is influencing activity.
    Kassiou and co-workers examined substitution of D3-trishomocubane for the development of Ï receptor ligands.(44) As part of that study they synthesized analogs 38 that examined the difference in phenyl (38a), cyclohexyl (38b), cubyl (38c), and a number of other substituted phenyl derivatives. The phenyl derivative 38a showed a Ki of 78 and 19 nM at the Ï1 and Ï2 receptors, respectively. Cyclohexyl substitution brought binding down to 4.0 and 1.9 nM, while the cubyl derivative showed a Ki of 3.0 nM at the Ï1 receptor and 2.0 nM at the Ï2 receptor. Improved affinity was argued through the increased 3D steric bulk associated with the cyclohexyl and cubyl moieties. Interestingly, some selectivity was also lost with 38c, as increased affinity for the dopamine transporter was observed (Ki = 126 nM), whereas the phenyl derivative 38a had a Ki of 3480 nM, and the cyclohexyl derivative lacked affinity.
    What seems to be more common in SAR studies is the comparison of cubane with other polycyclics, most commonly adamantane (Figure 5). Cubane differs from adamantane in terms of its reduced size and lipophilicity while also showing increased metabolic stability.(45) Polycyclic differences have been examined with GluN2B-containing N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptors.(40,46) While no direct comparison with the phenyl derivative was reported, the 3-fluorophenyl-containing compound 39a showed one of the best affinities, with a Ki of 2.86 nM. Converting to the adamantyl compound 39b saw a significant reduction in affinity (Ki = 4810 nM) which was mostly regained through the incorporation of cubane (Ki = 150 nM). These results provide a key example of how the steric bulk of the adamantane ring system can be detrimental and that by using cubane, this issue can be reduced. Given the different affinities obtained by changing phenyl substitution, it suggests the need to examine different cubane substitution patterns.
    Given the considerable lipophilicity associated with polycyclic building blocks, such entities have made a number of appearances in drugs designed for the central nervous system.(47) One such example is the cation-selective ion channel P2X purinoceptor 7 (P2X7R).(27,48) It has been shown that the cyanoguanidine 40 gave the best results when flanked by a hydrogen-bond-accepting aromatic ring and an adamantane moiety linked by a methylene unit.(49) Additional studies were then reported examining the role of the polycyclic moiety.(48) The inhibitory activity of 40a (IC50 = 57 nM) was significantly reduced when cubane was incorporated into the system (IC50 = 3467 nM) to give 40b. In this instance, the importance of steric bulk was clearly exemplified.
    Also with the P2X7R, a range of polycycles linked via an amide bond to an aromatic moiety (41) have also been reported.(27,29) A change from the adamantane 41a to cubane 41b saw an increase in IC50 from 10 nM to 436 nM, while the D3-trishomocubane 41c saw a smaller change to 32 nM. Interestingly, the closo-1,2-carborane derivative 41d saw a small improvement in potency, with an IC50 of 8 nM. With these examples, there is a clear correlation between the size of the polycyclic cage and inhibition of the P2X7R observed, with bigger polycyclic groups being more effective in the inhibition of this receptor. These reports also evaluated the lipophilicity of the various polycycles.(27,29) As expected, cubane is less lipophilic than the adamantane and closo-carborane cage, though calculated values from various computational methods can be quite removed from those determined experimentally. For example, the HPLC-determined logÂ D7.4 for 41b was 3.42 while the cLogP was calculated as 1.46,(27) though different experimental results gave a logÂ D7.4 of 2.90 and cLogP and logÂ P of 2.67 and 1.94, respectively.(29) The discrepancy between these results has yet to be rationalized.
    The adenosine A1 receptor agonists 42 were synthesized and provide a comparison between the cubane and trishomocubane (45) substituents.(50) In this example, the cubane derivative 42b showed vastly superior results over the D3-trishomocubane 42a, in both binding (Ki = 363 nM vs 3838 nM) and activity (EC50 = 14 nM vs 3438 nM). In this example, the smaller cubane group was better accommodated in the N6-binding pocket of the receptor.
    Utilizing the scaffolds 43(51) and 44,(52) Emmitte and co-workers have explored substitution of many cyclic and polycyclic moieties for metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR) negative allosteric modulation. When testing against mGluR 1, the adamantyl compound 43a gave an IC50 of 85 nMâ¯(51) whereas the cubane compound 43b had an IC50 greater than 10â¯000 nM. In this instance, the cyclohexyl and tert-butyl compounds (43c and 43d, respectively) also lost all activity. This was replicated with compound 44a, with the IC50 of 161 nM going above 10â¯000 nM for compounds 44bâd.(52) Given the loss of activity for all aliphatic substitutions, these results suggest more about the success of the adamantyl group rather than any obvious trend of cubane substitution.
    Monosubstituted cubanes have also made multiple appearances in the patent literature (Figure 6). However, detailed biological data have not been included, meaning that the role cubane plays in modulating activity is difficult to quantify. Compound 47 was shown to be an inhibitor of receptor interacting protein kinase 1 at less than 1 Î¼M but so were many other compounds, with both cyclic and acyclic substituents, meaning that little benefit was attributed to the cubane.(53) Compounds 48 (with various aryl substitution patterns) also showed potent activity (0.01â10 nM) as casein kinase 1 inhibitors for subtypes Îµ and Î´.(54) Again, the cubane was one of many cyclic and acyclic analogs, all of which showed good activity. 49 showed a Ki of between 10 nM and 100 nM against muscarinic 4 receptor,(55) while 50 (and other cubane analogs) was patented as a metalloprotease inhibitor.(56)
    The number of cubane-related publications and patent filings, most of which have occurred since the turn of the 21st century, illustrates the increasing consideration that monosubstituted cubanes are getting for incorporation into pharmaceuticals. Multiply substituted cubanes have also made an impact and will be examined in the following sections.

    1,4-Disubstituted Cubanes

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Given that the key cubane building block is the aforementioned 1,4-disubstituted ester 3, disubstituted cubanes in medicinal chemistry tend to have a 1,4-disubstitution pattern. Exceptions to this will be discussed in the next section. Multiple cubane building blocks with 1,4-disubstitution have been prepared using 3, or its monohydrolyzed derivative 9, and performing chemistry similar to that outlined in Scheme 1 but without the preceding decarboxylation step. For example, monoacid 9 can be converted to the chlorinated derivative 51a,(40) brominated derivative 51b,(57) and iodinated derivative 51c(44) through radical chemistry (Scheme 3). The iodo group can be further converted to the fluoride 51d using XeF2.(58) Functional group manipulations of the ester group of 51c lead to compound 52.(18,59)
    The Boc-protected amine 53 can be derived through a Curtius rearrangement and trapping with tert-butanol.(40) Deprotection of 53 to give the hydrochloride salt 54(40) and methylation to furnish 55(60) have both been reported. Given the halogen handles available in 51, multiple attempts have been made at cross-coupling reactions,(31,61â63) including conversion to metal and metalloid derivatives for transmetalation in the cross-coupling step.(59) However, these attempts have been unsuccessful, largely due to the instability of cubane in the presence of palladium. The incorporation of a phenyl group has been successful by using Pb(OAc)4 catalyzed free-radical arylation with benzene and the carboxylic acid 9,(64) using PhLi and substituting an iodo group,(65) and using ZnPh2 and a redox-active ester.(66) Lithiation of 52 and addition of electrophiles have also allowed for additional substitution, including elaboration with silicon, sulfur, phosphorus, and metal electrophiles.(59) However, it is only with a recent report that a cross-coupling-like reaction with cubanes has been reported.(67) Building upon the redox-active ester approach,(66) compound 56 was first synthesized and then reacted with various arylzinc reagents in the presence of a nickel catalyst to afford aryl-substituted analogs 57. In this approach, rather than an oxidative addition step, a single electron transfer was utilized to generate the active species for coupling. A general reaction scope was reported with electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups tolerated. Naphthyl and porphyrin substituents were also coupled using this procedure. This work illustrates the growing interest in cubane, and the novel approaches that must be utilized to obtain higher functionalization. As more work is reported, this is likely to have a profound effect and lead to an expansion of medicinal applications of cubane.
    Functionalization to produce symmetrical 1,4-disubstitution has also been reported, generally as a method of using cubane as a linking moiety (Scheme 4). Exhaustive saponification of 3 affords the dicarboxylic acid 58,(28) which can be converted to the diamine 59 via the Boc-protected amine and dihydrochloride salt.(68) Reduction of 3 to give the diol 60(30) allows for oxidation to the dialdehyde 61.(31) The aldehydes can be converted to the terminal dialkyne 62a or TMS-protected dialkyne 62b.(31) Selective removal of a single TMS group affords the unsymmetrical dialkyne 62c. Sonogashira coupling with the terminal alkynes was successfully employed, confirming that palladium insertion directly to the cubane is the problem associated with cubane in cross-coupling reactions.(31)
    The use of cubane as part of a SAR study was first reported by Hasegawa and co-workers for the development of antiulcer agents (Figure 7).(69) The majority of these efforts were directed at altering the linking amide of the cubane 63 to examine its effect on activity. A single homocubane analog was also reported, although comparison to other functionality was not made. The disubstituted cubane with dual amide appendages was shown to be necessary to retain potency. Though interestingly, 1,2- and 1,3-disubstituted cubanes lost activity. When the piperidinyl amide was used, good oral antiulcer activity was observed, although in the gastric fistula rat model, no activity was observed.(69)
    Radiolabeled compound 64 (123I) was developed as a probe for in vivo Staudinger ligation to azide tagged antibodies.(70) In comparison to desferrioxamine type probes with 89Zr or 67/68Ga radiolabeling, compound 64 showed poor pharmacokinetics and thus was not explored further in this study. As a way to improve upon compound 14a for inhibition of monoamine oxidase B, the series of compounds 14b,c were synthesized.(71) The improved activity observed for 14b,c showed that disubstitution was advantageous. Compound 14d was one of the first cubane containing molecules to appear in the patent literature as antiviral agents.(72) Oral administration of 14d to mice infected with influenza A2/AA/2/60 virus showed a survival rate of 70%, greater than the 20% observed for nontreated mice. No comparison to other compounds was provided.
    Polymers for the release of morphine have been developed from diisocyanate compound 65 through the incorporation of amide linkages (Figure 7).(73) Compound 66 has also been developed as a polymerization precursor. Subjecting 66 to free radical copolymerization with various drugs leads to novel and targeted delivery systems.(74â82) Nitroxyalkyl groups substituted onto cubane with various linkers have been developed and explored for their anti-ischemic activity (compounds 67).(83) Compound 67a showed an improved ratio between the necrotic and ischemic zones (36.1%) when compared to the lead compound nicorandil (68, 42.0%), where a mononitroxyalkyl is substituted on a pyridine. Importantly, the cubane derivative also showed reduced acute toxicity in relation to the commercially available agent nicorandil (LD50 = 800 mg kgâ1 for 67a and 475 mg kgâ1 for 68).
    The comparison between 1,4-disubstituted cubanes and 1,4-disubstituted phenyl groups has also been reported (Figure 8).(40) Compound 69a (leteprinim) has been shown to increase neurite outgrowth with potential neuroprotective properties.(84,85) A head-to-head comparison between 69a and the cubane analog 69b showed that both compounds enhanced the ability for nerve growth factor to enhance neurite growth. In this instance, the cubane analog 69b actually showed a greater effect than the phenyl lead 69a (approximately 48% vs 38% differentiated neurons, respectively). The common pain medication benzocaine (70a) was also compared to the cubane analog 70b in a noxious heat stimulus test with results showing the same local anesthetic efficacy between the compounds.(40) The role of cubane in pesticides was also investigated through comparison of diflubenxuron (71a) and the corresponding cubane analog 71b. Investigating these compoundsâ ability to illicit mortality of larval Tribolium castaneum showed an approximate 2-fold improvement for the cubane derivative 71b over 71a. These results indicate that while cubane offers a viable alternative to the phenyl group, no clear prediction of the expected pharmacology can be made. There is a much greater correlation in logÂ PHPLC between the 1,4-disubstituted cubane and phenyl derivatives than when compared to the monosubstituted compounds discussed earlier. Compounds 69a and 69b have an experimental value of 1.35 and 0.99, respectively, compounds 70a and 70b have values of 1.16 and 1.23, respectively, and compounds 71a and 71b have values of 3.33 and 3.13. These results suggest that when cubane has limited substitution, and little other functionality exists in the molecule, this can significantly alter the lipophilicity of phenyl to cubyl substitutions.
    1,4-Disubstituted cubanes have produced a bigger impact in SAR studies examining their use as a linker, allowing for comparison to simple cyclic spacers, such as cyclobutane or cyclohexane, and polycyclic residues such as bicyclo[1.1.1]pentane (72), bicyclo[2.2.2]octane (73), adamantane (74), and bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane (75) (Figure 9). Compounds 76 were analyzed for nonspecific binding, and the results obtained showed that the 72-linked compound 76c had a much lower propensity for nonspecific binding compared to 76a, 76b, and 76d.(86)
    Compounds 77 with various polycyclic rings and iodo substitution were synthesized as potential ligands for single photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT) imaging of the serotonin 1A (5-HT1A) receptor.(87) Compounds 77a, 77c, 77d all gave IC50 values less than 2.6 nM and Ki values of approximately 1 nM. The adamantyl analog 77b showed slightly reduced inhibition with an IC50 of 5.04 nM and Ki of 2.15 nM. The cubane compound 77a also showed selectivity when tested against other receptor subtypes. This investigation was initiated due to the poor metabolic stability profile of the lead compound 77e, which contained a cyclohexyl group rather than a polycycle and no iodination. Poor stability was not observed with the cubane polycycle nor was CâI bond cleavage, which allowed for 123I labeling for SPECT imaging by means of a copper-mediated transhalogenation of the âcoldâ bromo compound. Unfortunately, despite the improved stability of this molecule, it ultimately failed as a SPECT imaging agent due to its poor brain uptake and in vivo specificity.
    Given the initial success of the compounds 77, further modifications were made in an attempt to image 5-HT1A using positron emission tomography (PET). For this goal, compounds 78 were synthesized, including the 18F tracers for imaging.(88,89) In rats, all three compounds showed a higher uptake in the hippocampus and cortex, regions where the 5-HT1A receptor would be expected. Compound 78a showed slightly higher uptake in the liver than 78b, which was explained by the enhanced hepatic processing of the cubyl moiety.(90,91) The brain uptake of 78c was higher than 78a and 78b, which were almost identical, and selectivity for 5-HT1A was demonstrated by means of competitive binging studies. Unfortunately, during these studies rat bone uptake was observed, resulting from defluorination, again with 78a and 78b showing faster bone uptake than 78c. While ultimately unsuccessful for imaging applications, this work does nicely illustrate the different role cubane can sometimes have as a linking functionality in medicinal chemistry.
    The Abelson murine leukemia viral oncogene homolog 1 (ABL1) kinase inhibitor imatinib (79a) was subjected to an SAR study incorporating cyclic linking groups.(92) Compounds 79b and 79c showed higher thermodynamic solubility than other analogs, including the parent 79a, but lost inhibitory activity against the ALB1 kinase, with IC50 values of >1 Î¼M and >30 Î¼M, respectively. When examined in cell cytotoxicity assays, cubane-containing compound 79b still performed the best of the new analogs against KU-812 and MEG-01 cells, with estimated EC50 values of 1.4 Î¼M and 1.8 Î¼M, respectively. Though lead compound 79a showed submicromolar potency, this could be attributed to its potency against ABL1. Given the lack of ALB1 activity for 79b, it was suggested that off-target effects were causing the cytotoxicity, though which targets these are is not currently known.
    Various polycyclic linkers were also explored as inhibitors of Brutonâs tyrosine kinase, namely, compounds 80.(93) In all cases, IC50 values between 0.1 and 0.4 nM were found, indicating great tolerance for this alteration. Potencies translated to human peripheral blood mononuclear cell and human whole blood activity studies. Compounds 80a and 80b showed a greater reduction in potency in those studies compared to the bridged cyclohexyls 80c and 80d. It should be noted that the cubane compound 80a differed slightly in that it had a remote aromatic F-substitution (X = F) while the others lacked this substitution (X = H). Despite these encouraging results, compounds 80aâd were hampered by increased adenosine uptake inhibition, which has potential negative effects on the cardiovascular system.
    A comparison between phenyl, 72, and cubane linkers was made with compounds 81, antagonists of metabotropic glutamate receptor 1 (mGluR1). These results showed that the phenyl ring in 81a is not necessary for activity at the receptor, provided that a suitable spacer, such as that observed with 81c, is able to keep the amino acidic moiety and distal carboxylate in a colinear arrangement.(94) When investigating the cubane-linked 81b, despite maintaining the colinear arrangement, it showed a 9-fold decrease in potency, which was ascribed to the increase in volume of the spacer.(95) Despite the low potency of 81b at mGluR1, it showed greater selectivity than either 81a or 81c, as it was devoid of any effect at mGluR5, suggesting a more sterically demanding receptor. With these results, it was derivatives of 81c that were investigated further rather than the cubane-containing molecule.(96)
    Compounds 14eâj, developed as inhibitors of the fibrinolytic process, were some of the first molecules that contained a cubane moiety in a SAR study.(97) That study investigated the optimal distance between the carboxyl and amino groups by varying the linker. Lead compound 14e had a distance of 6.3 Ã between the carboxyl and amino groups and relative activity assigned as 1. Changing to the phenyl group (14f, 5.87 Ã) increased activity to a relative value of 3.7 while the cyclohexyl (5.82 Ã) had a relative value of 10.3. The 73 linked compound 14h (5.67 Ã) showed the best result of the screen with a relative activity of 103, while it was reduced to 5 for compound 14i (5.34 Ã). The 1,4-cubyl linked compound 14j, with a distance between the carboxyl and amino groups of 5.76 Ã, showed relative activity of 5. These results clearly illustrate how it is more than the distance between key functionalities, but also the properties of the linker, that influence biological activity.
    Cubane has also been featured as a linker in peptides, specifically as analogs to the cytotoxic natural products tubulysins (Figure 10).(60,98) These results showed that little tolerance for variation from the lead compound 84c was accepted at the amino terminus, and that included substitution to give analogs 82. While analogs 84 accepted some modifications, particularly aromatic linkers, the inclusion of 3D linkers such as cubane (84a) or 72 (84b) was not tolerated. However, analogs 83 showed that 3D linkers could be incorporated at the carboxyl end. Compounds 83 showed toxicity against cancer cell lines uterine sarcoma cells (MES SA), and human embryonic kidney cells (HEK 293T). The cubyl compound 83a showed comparable activity for both cell lines (IC50 = 0.84 nM and 0.26 nM at MES SA and HEK 293 T, respectively) to the 72-linked compound 83b (IC50 = 0.35 nM and 0.11 nM at MES SA and HEK 293 T, respectively).
    1,4-Disubstituted cubanes have also featured prominently in the patent literature (Figure 11). Compounds 85 were developed as prostaglandin D synthase inhibitors.(99) In addition to cubane, many cycloalkyl, aryl, heterocyclic, and polycyclic linkers were used. Though direct comparison with IC50 values is not possible, compounds 85 were reported with values between 10 and 79 nM. Compounds 86 were included in a screen as type II sodium dependent phosphate transporter 2A inhibitors with IC50 values of 7 and 9 nM for 86a and 86b, respectively.(99) While obviously showing reasonable results, a direct analog with another linker was not included to allow for an indication of the exact role of cubane.
    Compound 87 was tested against Janus kinases 1â3 and tyrosine kinase 2 (Tyk2) and displayed EC50 values of less than 100 nM, but so did a significant number of other noncubyl analogs.(100) Compound 88 was developed to target the human histamine H1 and H4 receptor and exhibited a Ki value, along with many other analogs, of less than 100 nM,(101) similarly for compound 89 and many noncubyl analogs showing an IC50 of less than 100 nM for phosphoinositide 3-kinases-Î³.(102) Compounds 90a(103) and 90b(104) were developed as antagonists for mGluR, though specific biological results were not provided, and the only analogs reported included the cubane moiety.
    Compound 91 was developed as a linker between two cytotoxic agents to generate bifunctional molecules.(105) While the linker was reported, along with other polycyclic linkers, examples of where they were conjugated to the cytotoxic agents were not reported, with only a propyl chain example being provided. Compound 90(106) was one of many analogs patented for targeting the HDM2 oncogene that regulates p53, though no biological data were included for this specific compound. Compounds 93 showed 100% inhibition of human 11-Î²-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 1 enzyme at 100 nM, but no unique role of the cubane was identified, as other analogs incorporating cyclic and polycyclic linkers also elicited the same result.(107)
    Compounds 94 were synthesized and tested against the human and mouse retinoid-related orphan receptor Î³.(108) Similar results were obtained for both species, but for the human receptor, 94a showed an EC50 of 32 nM, while 94b and 94c gave values of 38 nM and 21 nM, respectively. Compound 95 exhibited an IC50 between 0.1 and 1 Î¼M for the Janus kinase 3, but again, so did many other noncubane analogs.(109) More information could be gleaned from the IC50 values reported for compounds 96 at the retinoid-related orphan receptor Î³. Of related compounds, 96a showed the best value with an IC50 of 106 nM, while the analogs 96b and 96c had values of 1344 nM and 392 nM, respectively.(110) This is one of the clearest examples from the patent literature describing the benefit of a 1,4-disubstituted cubane analog. Compound 97 showed good activity against SET and MYND domain containing protein 3 (IC50 = 142 nM), which was also subjected to analysis in a cellular system (IC50 = 1308 nM). No clear advantage was suggested for the cubane linker over other moieties.(111)
    Compound 98 was reported as an adenosine receptor antagonist, but no specific biological results were reported.(112) Compound 99 gave an EC50 value of between 10 and 50 nM against ATF4 luciferase.(113)
    Compounds 100 were tested against matrix metalloproteinase 13, with results showing tolerance for both hydroxylmethyl and carboxylic acid substitution.(114) However, a clear advantage for the cubane linkage was shown, with both substituents showing improved binding compared to the 73 linkage (100aKi = 0.57 nM; 100bKi = 0.13 nM; 100cKi = 10.6 nM; 100dKi = 2.63 nM). Derivatives of compounds 49(54) and 50(56) with a simple second 1,4-disubstitution of the cubane moiety were also reported, but no quantification of biological data was provided.
    Compounds 101 were developed for treatment of fibrotic and inflammatory diseases through antagonism of the prostaglandin F2oC receptor.(115) Compound 101a gave an IC50 value of 73 nM which was the same result of the lead compound 101b. By comparison, using 72 as the linking unit to give 101c saw a 10-fold reduction in antagonism with an IC50 value of 723 nM. Compounds 102 were also included in SAR studies as inhibitors of prostaglandin D synthase inhibitors, and both showed similar results of pIC50 in the range of 7.1â8.0.(116) Finally, compounds 103 were included in a screen for novel pesticides.(117) In this instance, compounds 103aâc were ineffectual in the tests performed. Of related analogues reported in the patent, only the 1,2-disubstituted phenyl derivative 103d showed any activity. This exemplifies the necessity of investigated 1,2-disubstituted cubanes, as will be discussed in the following section.

    1,2- and 1,3-Disubstituted Cubanes

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Access to 1,2-disubstituted cubanes occurs through neighboring group participation, namely, using the ortho-lithiation approach (Scheme 5). Lithiation of amide 104, simply derived from acid 11 and a variety of amines with LiTMP, affords lithiated intermediate 105 that can be treated with an electrophile, e.g., CO2 to afford the 2-substituted acid 106.(118) Originally the diisopropyl amide (R = iPr) was used, which requires aggressive conditions to further manipulate (e.g., LiAlH4 followed by DMDO for conversion to a carboxylic acid),(2) but other amide examples also exist.(69) Transmetalation of the lithiated species(10â12) can also be used to broaden the scope of the transformation, as is the case here with magnesium. Unfortunately, no procedures for the conversion of 106 to 1,2-dicarboxylic acid 107 have been reported, but oxidation of the amide to the corresponding acid has been described for an analog of 106 wherein the carboxylic acid moiety is replaced with iodine,(119) and other suggested methods have also been reported.(120) Furthermore, the diacid 107 has been reported as a precursor to diisocyante 108 and then 109,(121) so it must be accessible. Direct irradiation of 11 in oxalyl chloride affords the diacid chloride but in 1:3:1 ratio between 1,2-, 1,3-, and 1,4-disubstition, making it a less than practical approach.(122)
    The application of 1,2-disubstituted cubanes in the medicinal chemistry field is limited. The 1,2-disubstituted analog of 63 (Figure 7) required a dosage 3 times that of 63 to elicit the same response,(69) and to date, it remains the only example.
    The synthesis of 1,3-disubstituted cubane 110 was first reported in 1966, starting with 111 and 112 and proceeding through intermediate 113 (Scheme 6).(123) Photocyclization of 113 in benzene to give 114 then allows for a double ring-contraction to give 110. Though reported, experimental details for these transformations are not provided. A second method was provided in 1970, starting with 115 and employing a dibromination to give 116 followed by photochemical rearrangement to furnish 117.(124) The authors then converted 117 into 110 following their procedures for the 1,4-disubstituted series,(22) though again no details were provided. Utilizing 118, which is obtained as a minor byproduct (4.5%) from the debromination and dimerization of 5,(118) conditions for the formation of 110 were provided. These involved a ring contraction to 119, followed by deprotection to 120, which then allows for a second ring contraction to give 110. Given the challenges with accessing 110, it becomes clear why 1,3-disubstition is not commonly observed in published cubane derivatives. In the case of the 1,3-substituted analog of 63 (Figure 7), it required a dosage 3 times that of 63 to elicit the same response.(69)

    Polysubstituted Cubanes

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cubane substitution has been reported all the way to octasubstituted derivatives (Figure 12). However, in these instances, substitution tends to involve the same functional group, as seen in the examples of 121b,(125)122,(126) and 123.(127) In the case of 122 and 123, new cubane syntheses were devised. For the nitro derivative 121b, it was synthesized from the heptanitrocubane (121a), itself derived from the tetranitrocubane.(125,128)
    Functionality can be introduced to the cubane scaffold through photochemical means, but regulation, both in terms of regiochemistry and level of substitution, can be difficult to control.(122) Also, this method limits the introduction of different functionalities.(129) To introduce variable substitution patterns with some degree of control is best achieved through a halogen handle(65,130) or a neighboring group directed lithiation approach (Scheme 7),(10,131â134) though admittedly this approach is quite step-intensive. Beginning with 1,4-disubsituted cubane 124, selective carboxylation leads to 125 which is then converted to the nitrile 126 to allow for a subsequent carboxylation to 127. Another nitrile formation gives 128, which allows for another carboxylation to give 129. Hydrolysis of the nitriles is selective, leaving the amide present in 130. Global carboxylic acid reduction and acetyl protection gives 131, which allows for an oxidative conversion of the amide to the acid 132. This pentasubstituted cubane 132 can be decarboxylated to the tetrasubstituted cubane 133.(131)
    Radical halogenation provides intermediates useful for the selective polysubstitution of cubane with different functional groups, but they are then difficult to incorporate into useful molecules.(135,136)
    Regardless of their challenging synthesis, polysubstituted cubanes have still been utilized by medicinal chemists (Figure 13). Cubane 134 showed moderate anti-HIV activity and 135 displayed moderate anticancer activity, although no identification of the R groups nor quantification of data or structural comparisons were provided.(137)
    The compounds 136 have been patented for their antiviral and anticancer properties, though no specific biological data were presented.(138)

    Conclusions and Outlook

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    From cubaneâs beginnings as a simple structural motif of limited, primarily theoretical interest to its application in high-energy materials, it is clear that this unique framework is now having a significant and sustained impact in medicinal chemistry. Indeed, the increasing use of the cubane scaffold in medicinal chemistry will undoubtedly open up new vistas in future drug discovery. The number of publications and patents that feature cubanes in a pharmaceutical context continues to increase each year owing to its benzene isosterism, defined 3D shape, and properties that differentiate it from other polycyclic caged molecules. As we look to the future, there is no doubt that the number of SAR explorations that feature cubane will continue to expand, allowing further insights into how it can be best utilized in pharmaceutical or agricultural contexts. The continued exploitation of cubanes will lead to a greater understanding of its metabolic processes, potential âpatent-bustingâ opportunities, and case studies involving inherent modulation of toxicity.
    The cubyl moiety offers a real opportunity to move away from the high number of aromatic molecules that are present in drug screening libraries, most likely a result of the popularity of cross-coupling as a method of functionalization. Phenyl to cubyl substitutions generally results in changes to lipophilicity, toxicity, and metabolism. The change in lipophilicity induced by a cubyl moiety compared to a phenyl moiety seems to depend on its level of substitution and if it is more exposed or predominates in the molecule. The toxicity of the cubane molecule itself is reduced when compared to benzene, but whether this trend holds when extensively functionalized molecules remains to be seen. Drug metabolism generally arises through oxidation by the cytochrome P450 superfamily, but given that aromatic hydroxylation usually occurs via epoxidation,(139) hydroxylation of the cubane core could be avoided. Alternatively, if hydroxylation proceeds via CâH insertion, it would be substantially decreased compared to a phenyl group and other polycyclic moieties, due to the hindered tertiary CâH bonds and increased s-character seen within the cubane nucleus.
    Current limitations of cubane center around its synthetic accessibility, beyond the commercially available dimethyl cubane-1,4-dicarboxylate. Multiple reports of functional group manipulations to generate many mono- and 1,4-disubstituted cubanes correspond to the medicinal applications that include these types of substitution patterns. To fully utilize cubane in drug discovery, its 3D positions need to be readily accessible. Simple and reliable procedures to access 1,2- and 1,3-disubstitution patterns, as well as polysubstitution, would greatly aid in the full exploration of cubaneâs role as a bioisostere. In particular, facile exploration of 3D spatial arrangements both âaboveâ and âbelowâ the benzene plane would be desirable. Given how the interest in high-energy materials resulted in multiple methods for nitrating cubane, the current attention given to cubane in medicinal chemistry will likely lead to the development of novel synthetic methodologies involving this moiety. Intriguingly, a common question raised is whether the isostructural aza-cubane 137 can exist (Figure 14). This molecule and the other polynitrogen containing cubane derivatives (e.g., 138â140, Figure 14) have to date only been the fodder of considerable theoretical debate.(140â144) That said, should any of these aza-cubanes become synthetically viable, one could easily imagine access to a new class of nitrogen-containing heterocyclic isosteres and offer a solution to the potential lipophilicity issues associated with cubane itself.
    Although at this point in time a cubane drug has yet to enter the clinic, the substantial enthusiasm in deploying the cubane framework within several medicinal chemistry programs strongly suggests that this structural motif will, in the not too distant future, likely reveal itself in clinical practice.

    The authors declare the following competing financial interest(s): C. M. W. has formal and informal commercial relationships with companies developing and supplying cubane intermediates. The remaining authors declare no competing financial interest.

    5. 5
      Yildirim, T.; Gehring, P. M.; Neumann, D. A.; Eaton, P. E.; Emrick, T. Solid Cubane: A Brief Review. Carbon 1998, 36, 809â 815, Â DOI: 10.1016/S0008-6223(98)00009-8
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      5
      Solid cubane: a brief review
      Yildirim, T.; Gehring, P. M.; Neumann, D. A.; Eaton, P. E.; Emrick, T.
      Carbon (1998), 36 (5-6), 809-815CODEN: CRBNAH; ISSN:0008-6223. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
      It is relatively easy to predict the structural properties of a solid made of spherical mols. However this is not the case for a solid composed of cubic mols. such as solid cubane. The cubic structure of the cubane mol. gives rise to many unusual solid state properties. Here we present a brief review of new X-ray and neutron scattering studies along with our model calcns. of the structure and lattice dynamics of solid cubane. The low-temp. phase (below the transition temp. of 394 K) is rhombohedral with Î±=72.69Â° and a=5.20 Ã. Surprisingly, the crystal structure of cubane in the orientationally-disordered phase is not cubic, but instead remains rhombohedral with Î±=103.3Â°, far from the fcc value of 60Â°. The jump in lattice const. at this transition is 0.05 Ã, which corresponds to a 5.4% vol. expansion, among the largest ever obsd. Neutron inelastic scattering measurements indicate that the librons lie higher in energy than do the phonons, but that they soften rapidly with increasing temp. Remarkably, model calcns. predict the correct low and high-temp. crystal structures, and reveal cubane to be a text-book example of a system with anisotropic large-amplitude collective motions in the disordered phase. A review with 29 refs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXkvVKrtb0%253D&md5=8b3cdd8aa8ee1e504d80dd77fd1a1433

    15. 15
      Della, E. W.; Head, N. J.; Mallon, P.; Walton, J. C. Homolytic Reactions of Cubanes. Generation and Characterization of Cubyl and Cubylcarbinyl Radicals. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1992, 114, 10730â 10738, Â DOI: 10.1021/ja00053a008
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      15
      Homolytic reactions of cubanes. Generation and characterization of cubyl and cubylcarbinyl radicals
      Della, Ernest W.; Head, Nicholas J.; Mallon, Philip; Walton, John C.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1992), 114 (27), 10730-8CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      A series of 4-substituted cubyl radicals was generated by bromine atom abstraction from 4-substituted 1-bromocubanes. EPR observations showed that the cubyl radicals abstracted secondary hydrogen atoms from the Et groups of triethylsilane and decayed mainly by second-order combination reactions. tert-Butoxyl radicals abstracted hydrogen atoms from cubane at least 26 times more rapidly than from cyclopropane at -90Â°. Electron-withdrawing substituents on cubane greatly reduced this rate. tert-Butoxyl radicals selectively abstracted the cage hydrogens rather than primary Me hydrogens from methylcubane. Reaction of bromine atoms with cubane occurred at the carbon atoms directly by homolytic substitution, thus initiating a rearrangement sequence which ended when the 7-bromotricyclo[4.2.0.02,5]oct-3-en-8-yl radical rapidly transferred a bromine atom from mol. bromine. By contrast, reaction of cubane with chlorine atoms occurred predominantly via hydrogen abstraction. Cubylcarbinyl radicals were shown by EPR spectroscopy to rearrange with a rate const. â¥5 Ã 109 s-1 at 25Â°, by a cascade of three Î²-scissions. The first Î²-scission of the Î±-hydroxycubylcarbinyl radical occurred at ca. 10-3 times the rate for the parent cubylcarbinyl radical, enabling the former radical, and its rearrangement product, to be obsd. by EPR spectroscopy.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXjvVersA%253D%253D&md5=2e745d7acb6eebf77681ca5decf97831
    16. 16
      Fokin, A. A.; Lauenstein, O.; Gunchenko, P. A.; Schreiner, P. R. Halogenation of Cubane under Phase-Transfer Conditions: Single and Double CâH-Bond Substitution with Conservation of the Cage Structure. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2001, 123, 1842â 1847, Â DOI: 10.1021/ja0032677
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      16
      Halogenation of Cubane under Phase-Transfer Conditions: Single and Double C-H-Bond Substitution with Conservation of the Cage Structure
      Fokin, Andrey A.; Lauenstein, Oliver; Gunchenko, Pavel A.; Schreiner, Peter R.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2001), 123 (9), 1842-1847CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The first highly selective C-H chlorination, bromination, and iodination of cubane (1) using polyhalomethanes as halogen sources under phase-transfer (PT) conditions is described. Isomeric dihalocubanes with all possible combinations of Cl, Br, and I in ortho, meta, and para positions were also prepd. by this method; m-dihalo products form preferentially. Ab initio and d. functional theory (DFT) computations were used to rationalize the pronounced differences in the reactions of 1 with halogen (Halâ¢) vs. C-centered trihalomethyl (Hal3Câ¢) radicals (Hal = Cl, Br). For Hal3C radicals the C-H abstraction pathway is less unfavorable (ÎGâ¡298 = 21.6 kcal/mol for Cl3Câ¢ and 19.4 kcal/mol for Br3Câ¢ at B3LYP/6-311+G**//B3LYP/6-31G**) than the fragmentation of the cubane skeleton via SH2-attack on one of the C atoms of 1 (ÎGâ¡298 = 33.8 and 35.1 kcal/mol, resp.). In Stark contrast, the reaction of 1 with halogen atoms preferentially follows the fragmentation pathway (ÎGâ¡298 = 2.1 and 7.5 kcal/mol) and C-H abstraction is more unfavorable (ÎGâ¡298 = 4.6 and 12.0 kcal/mol). Computational results nicely agree with the behavior of 1 under PT halogenation conditions (Hal3Câ¢ is involved in the activation step) and under free-radical photohalogenation with Hal2 (Della, E. W., et al. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1992, 114, 10730). The incorporation of a second halogen atom preferentially in the meta position of halocubanes demonstrates the control of the regioselectivity by MO symmetry.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXhtFantLk%253D&md5=d00df8739dc9202e84d736a128f326f8

      Cubane system
      Eaton, Philip E.; Cole, Thomas, W., Jr.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1964), 86 (5), 962-4CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      I was prepd, from II in turn prepd. from 2-cyclopentenone via the 4-bromo deriv., 2,3,4-tribromocyclopentanone, and 2-bromocyclopentadienone. I refluxed with 50% aq. KOH gave III via a Favorskii reaction. The ring C-H bonds of III have approx. 32% s-character, a substantial rehybridization of normal tetrahedral C occurring to accommodate the geometric requirements of the cubane skeleton.

      The First CNS-Active Carborane: A Novel P2X7 Receptor Antagonist with Antidepressant Activity
      Wilkinson, Shane M.; Gunosewoyo, Hendra; Barron, Melissa L.; Boucher, Aurelie; McDonnell, Michelle; Turner, Peter; Morrison, Daniel E.; Bennett, Maxwell R.; McGregor, Iain S.; Rendina, Louis M.; Kassiou, Michael

      The preparation and fate of cubylcarbinyl radicals
      Eaton, Philip E.; Yip, Yu Chi
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1991), 113 (20), 7692-7CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      The cubylcarbinyl radical was generated from cubylcarbinyl bromide and from the N-hydroxy-2-pyridinethione ester of cubylacetic acid under various conditions favoring hydrogen-atom transfer to the radical. Only when selenophenol in high concn. is used as the hydrogen donor is any methylcubane formed. Otherwise the cubylcarbinyl radical rearranges. A mechanistic scheme accounting for their formation is presented; sequential Ï-bond breaking occurs regioselectively, favoring processes in which there is good overlap between the radical orbital and that of the breaking bond. The rate const. for ring cleavage of cubylcarbinyl radical was calcd. to be >2 Ã 1010 s-1, substantially greater than that of any radical derived to date from a satd. hydrocarbon system.

      Eaton, Philip E.; Galoppini, Elena; Gilardi, Richard
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1994), 116 (17), 7588-96CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      The authors have developed new methodol. for the synthesis of alkynylcubanes and have used these compds. to make rigid-rod mols. constructed of cubane and acetylene subunits. Systems with one or two acetylenic units between two cubanes were also prepd. Dimerizations and cross-coupling reactions of various 1,4-diethynylcubanes afforded longer rods.

      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      40
      Validating Eaton's Hypothesis: Cubane as a Benzene Bioisostere
      Chalmers, Benjamin A.; Xing, Hui; Houston, Sevan; Clark, Charlotte; Ghassabian, Sussan; Kuo, Andy; Cao, Benjamin; Reitsma, Andrea; Murray, Cody-Ellen P.; Stok, Jeanette E.; Boyle, Glen M.; Pierce, Carly J.; Littler, Stuart W.; Winkler, David A.; Bernhardt, Paul V.; Pasay, Cielo; De Voss, James J.; McCarthy, James; Parsons, Peter G.; Walter, Gimme H.; Smith, Maree T.; Cooper, Helen M.; Nilsson, Susan K.; Tsanaktsidis, John; Savage, G. Paul; Williams, Craig M.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (11), 3580-3585CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Pharmaceutical and agrochem. discovery programs are under considerable pressure to meet increasing global demand and thus require const. innovation. Classical hydrocarbon scaffolds have long assisted in bringing new mols. to the market place, but an obvious omission is that of the Platonic solid cubane. Eaton, however, suggested that this mol. has the potential to act as a benzene bioisostere. Herein, we report the validation of Eaton's hypothesis with cubane derivs. of five mols. that are used clin. or as agrochems. Two cubane analogs showed increased bioactivity compared to their benzene counterparts, while two other analogs displayed equal bioactivity and the fifth analog demonstrated only partial efficacy. Ramifications from this study are best realized by reflecting on the no. of bioactive mols. that contain a benzene ring. Substitution with the cubane scaffold where possible could revitalize these systems, and thus expedite much needed lead candidate identification.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitF2qt70%253D&md5=f213efe7f0e39910ded08a46884352a4
    41. 41
      Richon, V. M. Cancer Biology: Mechanism of Antitumour Action of Vorinostat (Suberoylanilide Hydroxamic Acid), a Novel Histone Deacetylase Inhibitor. Br. J. Cancer 2006, 95, S2â S6, Â DOI: 10.1038/sj.bjc.6603463
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      41
      Cancer biology: mechanism of antitumour action of vorinostat (suberoylanilide hydroxamic acid), a novel histone deacetylase inhibitor
      Richon, V. M.
      British Journal of Cancer (2006), 95 (Suppl. 1), S2-S6CODEN: BJCAAI; ISSN:0007-0920. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors represent a potential new class of antitumor agents. Vorinostat (suberoylanilide hydroxamic acid or SAHA) is a potent inhibitor of HDAC activity and has undergone initial evaluation in several Phase I and II clin. trials. HDACs are enzymes that catalyze the removal of the acetyl moiety from the lysine residues of proteins, including the core nucleosomal histones. Together with histone acetyltransferases (HATs), HDACs regulate the level of protein acetylation. Alterations in both HAT and HDAC activity have been reported to occur in cancer. HAT activity has been found to be disrupted by translocation, amplification, overexpression or mutation in a variety of cancers, including those of haematol. or epithelial origin. HDACs have been found to be overexpressed or assocd. with oncogenic transcription factors. Vorinostat induces growth arrest, differentiation or apoptosis in a variety of transformed cells. The antiproliferative effects of vorinostat are believed to be due to drug-induced accumulation of acetylated proteins, including the core nucleosomal histones and other proteins (e.g., BCL6, p53 and Hsp90). Phase I and II trials have been conducted for the oral formulations of vorinostat, and results show that vorinostat inhibits its target enzyme (HDAC) in peripheral mononuclear cells and tumor tissue at doses that are well tolerated. Antitumor activity has been seen in patients with both haematol. and solid tumors.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Currie, B. J.; McCarthy, J. S. Permethrin and Ivermectin for Scabies. N. Engl. J. Med. 2010, 362, 717â 725, Â DOI: 10.1056/NEJMct0910329

      43
      Permethrin and ivermectin for scabies
      Currie, Bart J.; McCarthy, James S.
      New England Journal of Medicine (2010), 362 (8), 717-725CODEN: NEJMAG; ISSN:0028-4793. (Massachusetts Medical Society)
      In a remote aboriginal community in tropical northern Australia, a mother comes to the health center with her 4-yr-old son, who has multiple sores on the skin of his arms and legs. He is treated with a single dose of i.m. penicillin G benzathine and with the application of topical 5% permethrin cream over his whole body. A week later, the pyoderma has substantially resolved, but the boy continues to scratch his hands and feet. The clinic nurse visits the family house and finds that skin sores are present on both infants who live in the household, three of the six young children, and one of the three adolescents. Some also have scratches and small interdigital excoriations, which are consistent with scabies. An infirm elderly aunt living in the house is found to have widespread areas of extensively crusted and scaly skin, which are esp. prominent on her hands, elbows, armpits, knees, and buttocks. All the household members are given topical permethrin, and the aunt is referred to the hospital for oral ivermectin therapy.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      45
      Pharmacological Evaluation of Novel Bioisosteres of an Adamantanyl Benzamide P2X7 Receptor Antagonist
      Wilkinson, Shane M.; Barron, Melissa L.; O'Brien-Brown, James; Janssen, Bieneke; Stokes, Leanne; Werry, Eryn L.; Chishty, Mansoor; Skarratt, Kristen K.; Ong, Jennifer A.; Hibbs, David E.; Vugts, Danielle J.; Fuller, Stephen; Windhorst, Albert D.; Kassiou, Michael
      ACS Chemical Neuroscience (2017), 8 (11), 2374-2380CODEN: ACNCDM; ISSN:1948-7193. (American Chemical Society)
      Adamantanyl benzamide 1 was identified as a potent P2X7R antagonist but failed to progress further due to poor metabolic stability. We describe the synthesis and SAR of a series of bioisosteres of benzamide 1 to explore improvements in the pharmacol. properties of this lead. Initial efforts investigated a series of heteroarom. bioisosteres, which demonstrated improved physicochem. properties but reduced P2X7R antagonism. Installation of bioisosteric fluorine on the adamantane bridgeheads was well tolerated and led to a series of bioisosteres with improved physicochem. properties and metabolic stability. Trifluorinated benzamide 34 demonstrated optimal physicochem. parameters, superior metabolic stability (ten times longer than lead benzamide 1), and an improved physicokinetic profile and proved effective in the presence of several known P2X7R polymorphisms.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtlyhtr7L&md5=6f1ee1daa1cccebc6859efde186eb39d

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      47
      Pharmaceuticals that contain polycyclic hydrocarbon scaffolds
      Stockdale, Tegan P.; Williams, Craig M.
      Chemical Society Reviews (2015), 44 (21), 7737-7763CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Numerous variations on structural motifs exist within pharmaceutical compds. that have entered the clinic. These variations have amounted over many decades based on years of drug development assocd. with screening natural products and de novo synthetic systems. Caged (or bridged) bicyclic structural elements offer a variety of diverse features, encompassing three-dimensional shape, and assorted pharmacokinetic properties. This review highlights approx. 20 all carbon cage contg. pharmaceuticals, ranging in structure from bicyclo[2.2.1] through to adamantane, including some in the top-selling pharmaceutical bracket. Although, a wide variety of human diseases, illnesses and conditions are treated with drugs contg. the bicyclic motif, a common feature is that many of these lipophilic systems display CNS and/or neurol. activity. In addn., to an extensive overview of the history and biol. assocd. with each drug, a survey of synthetic methods used to construct these entities is presented. An anal. section compares natural products to synthetics in drug discovery, and entertains the classical caged hydrocarbon systems potentially missing from the clinic. Lastly, this unprecedented review is highly pertinent at a time when big pharma is desperately trying to escape flatland drugs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFKitr7O&md5=b9b825abdcc6b98c8d409014983370ae

      The role of polycyclic frameworks in modulating P2X7 receptor function
      Callis, Timothy B.; Reekie, Tristan A.; O'Brien-Brown, James; Wong, Erick C. N.; Werry, Eryn L.; Elias, Nabiha; Jorgensen, William T.; Tsanaktsidis, John; Rendina, Louis M.; Kassiou, Michael
      Tetrahedron (2018), 74 (12), 1207-1219CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Herein the authors describe the recent attempts to target the P2X7 receptor for potential treatment of neurol. disorders. This work focuses on different polycycles including carborane, adamantane or cubane, joined by either a cyanoguanidine or an amide linker to Ph or isoquinoline moieties. The authors have demonstrated the superiority of the adamantyl moiety over other polycycles in terms of synthetic accessibility and biol. (cellular) activity. The authors have also shown that an amide or cyanoguanidine linker can greatly alter the biol. activity of compds. This SAR study provides important insights into the types of functionality required to target the P2X7 receptor.

      Discovery and pharmacological evaluation of a novel series of adamantyl cyanoguanidines as P2X7 receptor antagonists
      O'Brien-Brown, James; Jackson, Alexander; Reekie, Tristan A.; Barron, Melissa L.; Werry, Eryn L.; Schiavini, Paolo; McDonnell, Michelle; Munoz, Lenka; Wilkinson, Shane; Noll, Benjamin; Wang, Shudong; Kassiou, Michael
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 130 (), 433-439CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      Here we report adamantyl cyanoguanidine compds. based on hybrids of the adamantyl amide scaffold reported by AstraZeneca and cyanoguanidine scaffold reported by Abbott Labs. Compd. 27 displayed five-fold greater inhibitory potency than the lead compd. 2 in both pore-formation and interleukin-1Î² release assays, while 35-treated mice displayed an antidepressant phenotype in behavioral studies. This SAR study provides a proof of concept for hybrid compds., which will help in the further development of P2X7R antagonists.

      Synthesis and biological evaluation of adenosines with hetero-bicyclic and polycyclic N6-substituents as adenosine A1 receptor agonists
      Gosling, Joshua I.; Baker, Stephen P.; Haynes, John M.; Kassiou, Michael; Pouton, Colin W.; Warfe, Lyndon; White, Paul J.; Scammells, Peter J.
      ChemMedChem (2012), 7 (7), 1191-1201CODEN: CHEMGX; ISSN:1860-7179. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A concise synthesis of a series of N6-substituted adenosines with bicyclo[3.2.1]octan-6-yl and polycyclic N6-substituents has been developed. The adenosine A1 receptor (A1R) affinity and potency of these compds. was initially assessed using competitive binding assays and cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) accumulation assays in DDT1 MF-2 cells. The potency and receptor subtype selectivity of selected examples was further evaluated by measuring their effects on cAMP accumulation at all human adenosine receptor subtypes expressed in CHO cells. The results of these assays indicated that all of the synthesized N6-substituted adenosines are full agonists at A1R and activate this receptor selectively over the other adenosine receptor subtypes. The two standout compds. in terms of potency were N6-(3-thiabicyclo[3.2.1]octan-6-yl)adenosine and N6-(cubanyl-methyl)adenosine with EC50 values at human A1R of 2.3 nM and 1.1 nM, resp. The cubanylmethyl deriv. in particular proved to be highly receptor subtype selective. These two compds. were further evaluated in a simulated ischemia model in cultured cardiomyoblasts, where they were found to impart protective effects under hypoxic conditions that resulted in a significant redn. in cell death.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Synthesis of bridgehead fluorides by fluorodeiodination
      Della, Ernest W.; Head, Nicholas J.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1992), 57 (10), 2850-5CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
      Fluorodeiodination is found to be an attractive procedure for the synthesis of bridgehead fluorides. Fluorodeiodination is an attractive procedure for the synthesis of bridgehead fluorides. Thus, treatment of the corresponding iodide with xenon difluoride in dichloromethane at ambient temp. generally leads to high yields of the fluoride. Thus, treatment of the corresponding iodide with xenon difluoride in dichloromethane at ambient temp. generally leads to high yields of the fluoride. Evidence suggests the intermediacy of the bridgehead cation in this reaction, and accordingly the substrates which are unfavorably disposed to fluorodeiodination are the bicyclo[n.1.1]alkyl iodides. Evidence suggests the intermediacy of the bridgehead cation in this reaction; accordingly, the substrates which are unfavorably disposed to fluorodeiodination are the bicyclo[n.1.1]alkyl iodides. In this context the isolation of a small quantity of Me 4-fluorobicyclo[2.1.1]hexane-1-carboxylate is significant because it represents the first occasion on which the elusive 1-bicyclo[2.1.1.]hexyl cation has been trapped. In this context the isolation of a small quantity of Me 4-fluorobicyclo[2.1.1]hexane-1-carboxylate is significant because it represents the first occasion on which the elusive 1-bicyclo[2.1.1]hexyl cation has been trapped. The iodides can be synthesized efficiently by Barton halodecarboxylation and by treatment of the carboxylic acid with lead tetraacetate and iodine.

      59
      Highly Strained Tertiary sp3 Scaffolds: Synthesis of Functionalized Cubanes and Exploration of Their Reactivity under Pd(II) Catalysis
      Plunkett, Shane; Flanagan, Keith J.; Twamley, Brendan; Senge, Mathias O.
      Organometallics (2015), 34 (7), 1408-1414CODEN: ORGND7; ISSN:0276-7333. (American Chemical Society)
      A series of chem. distinct, highly strained, activated cubane scaffolds were synthesized through optimization of the metal-halogen exchange reactions of iodinated cubane derivs. This included the first reported successful attachment of both boron and phosphorus, key elements in potential transition-metal-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions, on the cubane scaffold. Addnl., Zn, Sn, Si, S, and various C-based systems were also attached in a high-yielding, one-pot reaction from readily available precursors. A comprehensive program investigating the reactivity of these tertiary cubane nucleophiles toward Suzuki-Miyaura, Negishi, and Stille cross-coupling methods, never previously reported with the cubane scaffold, is also described, but proved unsuccessful.

      Total Synthesis and Biological Evaluation of Natural and Designed Tubulysins
      Nicolaou, K. C.; Yin, Jun; Mandal, Debashis; Erande, Rohan D.; Klahn, Philipp; Jin, Michael; Aujay, Monette; Sandoval, Joseph; Gavrilyuk, Julia; Vourloumis, Dionisios
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2016), 138 (5), 1698-1708CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A streamlined total synthesis of N14-desacetoxytubulysin H (Tb1, I) based on a C-H activation strategy and a short total synthesis of pretubulysin D (PTb-D43, II) are described. Applications of the developed synthetic strategies and technologies to the synthesis of a series of tubulysin analogs (Tb2-Tb41 and PTb-D42) are also reported. Biol. evaluation of the synthesized compds. against an array of cancer cells revealed a no. of novel analogs (e.g., Tb14, III), some with exceptional potencies against certain cell lines [e.g., Tb32, IV, with IC50 = 12 pM against MES SA (uterine sarcoma) cell line and 2 pM against HEK 293T (human embryonic kidney) cell line], and a set of valuable structure-activity relationships. The highly potent cytotoxic compds. discovered in this study are highly desirable as payloads for antibody-drug conjugates and other drug delivery systems for personalized targeted cancer chemotherapies.

      Building with Cubane-1,4-diyl. Synthesis of Aryl-Substituted Cubanes, p-[n]Cubyls, and Cubane-Separated Bis(arenes)
      Eaton, Philip E.; Pramod, Kakumanu; Emrick, Todd; Gilardi, Richard
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1999), 121 (17), 4111-4123CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      On treatment with an organolithium 1,4-diiodocubane generates cubane-1,4-diyl, a highly reactive species, shown here to be a versatile precursor to numerous aryl substituted cubanes, e.g. I, available now for the first time in high yield. The diyl is demonstrated to provide a good route to bicubyl and its derivs. A kind of living polymn. of the diyl is developed to give the p-[n]cubyls, e.g. II. These oligomers are rigid rods made up of cubanes linked together at the 1 and 4 positions, each cubane adding â¼4.15 Ã to the length. The properties of these rods, some more than 15 Ã long, are discussed, as are methods for modifying their soly. X-ray crystallog. analyses of some of these compds. are presented, with emphasis on packing parameters.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXisVaqt7g%253D&md5=e6778542c7dd64123261b414567eb220

      Toriyama, F.; Cornella, J.; Wimmer, L.; Chen, T.-G.; Dixon, D. D.; Creech, G.; Baran, P. S. Redox-Active Esters in Fe-Catalyzed CâC Coupling. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2016, 138, 11132â 11135, Â DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b07172
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      66
      Redox-Active Esters in Fe-Catalyzed C-C Coupling
      Toriyama, Fumihiko; Cornella, Josep; Wimmer, Laurin; Chen, Tie-Gen; Dixon, Darryl D.; Creech, Gardner; Baran, Phil S.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2016), 138 (35), 11132-11135CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Cross-couplings of alkyl halides and organometallic species based on single electron transfer using Ni and Fe catalyst systems have been studied extensively, and sep., for decades. Here we demonstrate the first couplings of redox-active esters (both isolated and derived in situ from carboxylic acids) with organozinc and organomagnesium species using an Fe-based catalyst system originally developed for alkyl halides. This work is placed in context by showing a direct comparison with a Ni catalyst for >40 examples spanning a range of primary, secondary, and tertiary substrates. This new C-C coupling is scalable and sustainable, and it exhibits a no. of clear advantages in several cases over its Ni-based counterpart.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtlyqsrzI&md5=74aa696b51bc593e42905a23f776c9ac

      Bernhard, S. S. R.; Locke, G. M.; Plunkett, S.; Meindl, A.; Flanagan, K. J.; Senge, M. O. Cubane Cross-Coupling and CubaneâPorphyrin Arrays. Chem.âEur. J. 2018, 24, 1026â 1030, Â DOI: 10.1002/chem.201704344
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      67
      Cubane Cross-Coupling and Cubane-Porphyrin Arrays
      Bernhard, Stefan S. R.; Locke, Gemma M.; Plunkett, Shane; Meindl, Alina; Flanagan, Keith J.; Senge, Mathias O.
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2018), 24 (5), 1026-1030CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Herein, an improved methodol. for aryl-cubane cross-coupling is reported. The peculiarities of the cubane core and its behavior during cross-coupling conditions were analyzed, while the versatility of this adapted Baran cross-coupling methodol. was demonstrated by the synthesis of various aryl-cubane systems, including coupling products of cubanes and porphyrins and metalloporphyrins. Also, arm extension of alkynyl-cubanes by Sonogashira reactions is demonstrated, showcasing the 1st proof of the stability of the cubane core in the presence of Pd catalysts.
